body: Hey @ADmad, can you reproduce the issue on https://psalm.dev ?
Same issue for us, only on GitHub Actions though and with PHP 7.4.13: https://github.com/getkirby/kirby/runs/1701172723?check_suite_focus=true

This looks to be what started the bug https://github.com/vimeo/psalm/commit/b30842e9811718c02c1442b4ce465068273b836e#diff-34d358b776541824d633dce138ec8282f95adc5b7e12dabb31503e71edd8e9b1R2218
It probably cannot be reproduced in the aforementioned tool if it runs on PHP 8+ or there is a different version setting: https://github.com/vimeo/psalm/blob/0e17a3354fda992d7113b97d15c75ff4a92ad800/src/Psalm/Config.php#L1661

I'm pretty sure this is because of the `$codebase->php_major_version >= 8` check. If the analyzed code doesn't actually use any PHP 8 features yet, Psalm does not load the stub, which then breaks the `CoreGenericClasses.phpstub` that relies on the `Stringable` interface.

I'm wondering why the PHP 8 stubs are not always loaded for PHP versions < 8.0. Would that break something else or was it done for performance reasons?

issue.title: CI: Unpin Psalm version again
issue.body: The CI issue we were having yesterday [only occurs on PHP < 8.0](https://github.com/vimeo/psalm/issues/5007#issuecomment-761189112). On PHP 8.0 everything works fine, so we can now use the latest Psalm version in CI again.

body:
> I'm wondering why the PHP 8 stubs are not always loaded for PHP versions < 8.0. 

To correctly check your code Psalm needs *accurate* stubs. E.g. it would not flag calls to `ReflectionClass::getAttributes()` in the codebase targeting PHP 7.3 if it had loaded stubs for 8.0

OK, that makes sense.

How does Psalm know which PHP version(s) the codebase targets? And what if the code should be able to run on multiple different PHP versions like PHP 7.3-8.0?

In any case, the bug is basically that the version-independent stub for `SimpleXMLElement` uses `Stringable`. So maybe the fix is to have two different stubs for `SimpleXMLElement`: One for PHP 8 with `Stringable` and one for PHP < 8 without. Or maybe we can get rid of the use of `Stringable` completely.

> How does Psalm know which PHP version(s) the codebase targets?

In the order of preference:

1. CLI argument (`--php-version`)
2. Config file ([`phpVersion` attribute](https://psalm.dev/docs/running_psalm/configuration/#phpversion))
3. First of `5.4.0`, `5.5.0`, `5.6.0`, `7.0.0`, `7.1.0`, `7.2.0`, `7.3.0`, `7.4.0`, `8.0.0` that satisfies your `composer.json` constraints (`require.php` key), if you have any.

>  And what if the code should be able to run on multiple different PHP versions like PHP 7.3-8.0?

Run Psalm multiple times, with `--php-version=7.3`, `--php-version=7.4`, etc.

> How does Psalm know which PHP version(s) the codebase targets? And what if the code should be able to run on multiple different PHP versions like PHP 7.3-8.0?

https://psalm.dev/docs/running_psalm/configuration/#phpversion

> In any case, the bug is basically that the version-independent stub for `SimpleXMLElement` uses `Stringable`. So maybe the fix is to have two different stubs for `SimpleXMLElement`: One for PHP 8 with `Stringable` and one for PHP < 8 without. Or maybe we can get rid of the use of `Stringable` completely.

Maybe a stub for Stringable with just a __toString method could make it work for every version?

> Maybe a stub for Stringable with just a __toString method could make it work for every version?

No. Such a stub would incorrectly add `Stringable` to the namespace of a codebase which may not have in fact. Hence, leading to incorrect analysis results.

I think Psalm needs to support different stubs for different versions, and the stubs would be grandfathered if the new PHP version has not changed the interface. Now it seems fairly chaotic.

I'd not call this a big deal.

Psalm already adds every stubbed class in every old version of PHP if I'm not mistaken. The only impact I can see is if a codebase not yet in PHP8 use Stringable without Polyfill. In this case, Psalm would not return an error.

It seems like an acceptable compromise given the additional burden of creating and maintaining versionned stubs. I guess if you're up for it, it'd would be nice to have, but otherwise, I'm not sure it's a reasonable fix for this issue.

@weirdan @orklah Thank you very much for the insights on the `phpVersion` option and flag. üëç

Regarding this issue: Do we really need to have `implements \Stringable` in [this line](https://github.com/vimeo/psalm/commit/b30842e9811718c02c1442b4ce465068273b836e#diff-34d358b776541824d633dce138ec8282f95adc5b7e12dabb31503e71edd8e9b1R2218)? As PHP 8.0 automatically adds the `Stringable` interface to every class implementing `__toString()`, wouldn't it be an alternative to include the method definition of `__toString()` in the `SimpleXMLElement` stub? This would make the stub compatible with all PHP versions.

> Regarding this issue: Do we really need to have `implements \Stringable` in [this line](https://github.com/vimeo/psalm/commit/b30842e9811718c02c1442b4ce465068273b836e#diff-34d358b776541824d633dce138ec8282f95adc5b7e12dabb31503e71edd8e9b1R2218)? As PHP 8.0 automatically adds the `Stringable` interface to every class implementing `__toString()`, wouldn't it be an alternative to include the method definition of `__toString()` in the `SimpleXMLElement` stub? This would make the stub compatible with all PHP versions.

This could be a solution but Psalm should not report this as an error:
https://3v4l.org/8WKd9
Which I think it will if we remove Stringable from the stubs

Could this be solved by implementing the "magic `Stringable` interface behavior" from PHP 8 in Psalm as well? Meaning: Like PHP, Psalm should automatically add the `Stringable` interface to every class that implements `__toString()` if the `phpVersion` option is set to `8.0` or higher.
Not sure. It may already be the case. You could try to push a PR to test that üòÉ
To be honest I don't have a good overview over the Psalm codebase, so I wouldn't know where to start. If someone wants to continue with the idea, go ahead. :)

> To be honest I don't have a good overview over the Psalm codebase, so I wouldn't know where to start. If someone wants to continue with the idea, go ahead. :)

No need to know the internals, There's a file ToStringTest in tests/ directory, you could add my example in it. You then try to remove \Stringable in the stubs. If it pass, the issue is resolved. If it doesn't pass, we'll need to refine the solution or try another one üòÑ

repository.name: psalm
repository.description: A PHP static analysis tool for finding errors and security vulnerabilities in PHP applications

body:
@orklah Ah, right! I misunderstood your message. It turns out there is [already a test case for exactly this behavior](https://github.com/vimeo/psalm/blob/4.4.1/tests/ToStringTest.php#L172-L186), so we are fine.

I have fixed this issue in https://github.com/vimeo/psalm/pull/5037.
